Comment:
This is a great game with immediate aggression from White, that once started could not be stopped. Only continued forced Check moves kept me alive.
There were many places where the wrong aggressive play would have backfire into a Checkmate against me. 

I thought I would try to understand the King gambit by playing it

I thought I would try to understand the King gambit by playing it
declined...OK, I'll just play it as if it was taken
which is this move
maybe I'll sacrifice my bishop to eliminate his castle option
maybe I'll sacrifice my bishop to eliminate his castle option
but then what...
This will constrict my bishop, but my queen can keep pressure on
this doesn't change my plan
I went for it
forced
as planned...
simple block
Why not...

Whoa...I expected a retreat.
I took a couple of days to calculate the next move.

Advancing the f pawn for check was enticing, hoping he would go to h5 for a triple fork.
Even taking my knight COULD work out...

That move would have been risky---I found several ways for this to backfire into a checkmate for myself.
Bishop taking that pawn was would have been the best counter to that move, but other responses were shaky for me as well.

so, I'll just protect what I have so far...
and having this bishop diagonal open is crucial in the long run
OK, the knight has to move
now his King can't take the knight
but there's that bishop
I had to take it. It isolates the pawn, but I can't castle with that bishop there and I won't do well against 2 bishops with this pawn structure
hmmm, if he had left that hanging pawn there, he probably would have taken it eventually...

Now the fork is available
I was worried that I was taking out a rook that might not threaten anytime soon.
Would have been better off getting my pieces out?

IF I can continue play, this play will be worth it
